title-group.article-title: The Injured and Regenerating Nervous System
title-group.subtitle: Immunoglobulin Superfamily Members as Key Players

article-meta.aff: 1Neuroscience Laboratory, Department of Otorhinolaryngology, University of Jena, Germany
2Zentrum für Molekulare Neurobiologie, Universität Hamburg, Hamburg, Germany
3Keck Center for Collaborative Neuroscience, Department of Cell Biology and Neuroscience, Rutgers University, Piscataway, NJ, USA

author-notes.corresp: Andrey Irintchev, Department of Otorhinolaryngology, Friedrich Schiller University Jena, Lessingstrasse 2, D-07740 Jena, Germany Email: andrey.irintchev@med.uni-jena.de

abstract.p: Understanding restricted functional recovery and designing efficient treatments to alleviate dysfunction after injury of the nervous system remain major challenges in neuroscience and medicine. Numerous molecules of potential significance in neural repair have been identified in vitro, but only few of these have proved to be of major importance in vivo up to now. Among the molecules involved in regeneration are several members of the immunoglobulin superfamily, most notably the neural cell adhesion molecules L1, its close homologue CHL1, and NCAM and, in particular, its polysialic acid glycan moiety. Sufficient evidence is now available to justify the statement that these molecules are major players not only in nervous system development but also in the adult during neural repair and synaptic plasticity. Importantly, insights into the functions of these molecules in promoting or inhibiting functional recovery have allowed the design and assessment of therapeutic approaches in animal models of central nervous system injury that could prove to be applicable in clinical settings.

body.p: The immunoglobulin superfamily (IgSF) is one of the most ancient and diverse groups of proteins, a “master superfamily of interaction molecules,” including thousands of different proteins expressed in diverse organs and systems of vertebrates and invertebrates (Barclay 2003; Shapiro and others 2007). The evolutionary success of the IgSF members is related to one common structural element, a variable domain that shares amino acid sequence similarities with immunoglobulins and allows versatile molecular interactions. The origin of the IgSF concept dates back to the late 1970s when a protein expressed in the brain, the thymocyte differentiation antigen 1 (Thy-1), was identified as an immunoglobulin-like molecule (Campbell and others 1979). Since then, the number of neural IgSF members and understanding of their molecular structure, interaction partners, and signaling mechanisms have dramatically increased (Brümmendorf and Rathjen 1996; Maness and Schachner 2007; Rougon and Hobert 2003; Shapiro and others 2007; Walsh and Doherty 1997). In addition to knowledge on structure-function relationships of IgSF members in vitro, substantial progress has been made in understanding their functions in vivo. It is now well established that several molecules, known as immunoglobulin cell adhesion molecules (IgCAMs), are crucial for normal brain development. Genetic ablation of the IgCAMs NCAM, L1, and CHL1 leads to structural aberrations in the brain and abnormal behavioral traits in mice, and mutations in the human genes encoding these proteins are linked to major neuropsychiatric disorders, such as schizophrenia (NCAM, L1, CHL1) and mood disorders (NCAM; Maness and Schachner 2007). The origins of such disorders are due to disturbances of developmental processes mediated by IgCAMs that include cell proliferation and migration, neuritogenesis, axonal fasciculation, synaptogenesis, and stabilization of synapses. An impressive development was the identification of several IgCAMs expressed in the adult brain as major determinants of synaptic plasticity and thus of learning and memory (Dityatev and others 2008). Not least, evidence has accumulated indicating that IgSF molecules are involved in repair of the injured adult nervous system (Loers and Schachner 2007; Zhang Y and others 2008). Considering the properties identified in vitro, such as promotion of cell survival and neuritogenesis, the list of IgSF molecules of interest for regeneration after injury in the central and peripheral nervous system is remarkable, but convincing evidence for major impacts on neural repair in vivo is limited to a few IgCAMs—NCAM, L1, and CHL1—which are the main topic of this review.

sec.title: Molecular and Functional Diversity of IgCAMs
sec.p: The functional roles that IgCAMs may play in neural repair are considered to be multiple, and even a single molecule can have both regeneration-promoting and - inhibiting properties depending on the cellular context that such molecules are expressed in. To clarify this notion, it is worthwhile to consider some structural features providing a basis for a high functional diversity of IgCAMs at different levels (Fig. 1) (Brümmendorf and Rathjen 1996; Kleene and Schachner 2004; Maness and Schachner 2007; Schmid and Maness 2008). First, several structurally distinct Ig domains allow interactions with the same molecule (homophilic binding) and non-like molecules (heterophilic interactions) located within the same cell surface membrane (cis-interactions) and on neighboring cells (trans-interactions). Alternatively spliced isoforms with small inserted sequences intra- and extracellularly convey, respectively, distinct signal transduction and recognition features of IgCAMs. In addition, several IgCAMs possess fibronectin type 3 (FN3)–like domains, which bind to molecules distinct from the binding partners of the Ig domains. As a result of the diversity of binding domains, L1, for example, can bind to several molecules, including L1, NCAM, neuropilin-1, integrins, TAG-1 (transient axonal glycoprotein-1), F3/contactin, CD9, and CD24 (Maness and Schachner 2007). Second, posttranslational modifications lead to developmentally and cellular activity regulated glycosylation patterns that alter the functional properties of IgCAMs (Kleene and Schachner 2004). A most striking and well-known example is the unusual glycan α2,8 polysialic acid (PSA), a linear homopolymer attached to the fifth Ig domain of NCAM that can contain up to 200 sialic acid residues (Fig. 1). PSA reduces the adhesive properties of NCAM via its highly negative charge and/or large hydration volume and could also act in a heterophilic mode by affecting interactions of NCAM with other molecules such as heparan sulfate proteoglycans or, surprisingly, histone H1 (Mishra and others 2010). Third, the extracellular domains of IgCAMs can be enzymatically cleaved by members of the ADAM (a disintegrin and metalloprotease) family, leading to enrichment of the extracellular matrix with functionally active IgCAM fragments (Maness and Schachner 2007). Thus, for example, L1 cleavage promotes neuronal cell migration and neurite outgrowth. Fourth, additional functional and structural diversity is achieved by alternative splicing of the IgCAMs (Fig. 1) (Doherty and others 2000; Maness and Schachner 2007). For NCAM, a single gene gives rise to three major isoforms, NCAM120, NCAM140, and NCAM180 (Fig. 1). In addition, a variable alternatively spliced exon (VASE) can be inserted in the fourth Ig domain, causing down-regulation of NCAM-mediated axon growth or truncation and secretion of the NCAM extracellular domain.

caption.p: Structure of immunoglobulin cell adhesion molecules (IgCAMs). Shown are molecules belonging to three different subfamilies defined by their extracellular domain organization (Brümmendorf and Rathjen 1996; Cunningham 1995): the n/0 subfamily (n Ig domains, 0 FN3 repeats, MAG), the 5/2 subfamily (NCAM), and the 6/5 (L1) subfamily (L1, CHL1). Extra and intra indicate the extra- and intracellular side of the cell surface membrane presented as a horizontal gray line. NCAM120 is attached to the membrane via a GPI (glycosylphosphatidylinositol) anchor. The other IgCAMs are type I proteins with a transmembrane and an intracellular domain. NCAM is encoded by a single gene, and its three major isoforms with apparent molecular weights of 120, 140, and 180 kD (NCAM120, NCAM140, and NCAM180, respectively) are generated by alternative splicing. NCAM120 and NCAM140 are expressed by glial cells and NCAM140 and NCAM180 by neurons. Alternatively spliced sequences are found in the cytoplasmic domain and the second Ig domain of L1 (Maness and Schachner 2007), and the cytoplasmic domain of MAG yields a large (L) or a small (S) MAG isoform (Quarles 2007). All IgCAMs are glycoproteins, and potential glycosylation sites attached to the protein backbone (Holm and others 1996; Kleene and Schachner 2004; Kruse and others 1984) are indicated by green circles. The human natural killer cell glycan (3′ sulfoglucuronyl β1,3 galactoside), known as HNK-1 epitope, is expressed on all IgCAM members shown here. The glycosylation of NCAM is unusual in that it carries, in addition to other glycans, α2,8 polysialic acid (PSA) polymers within its fifth Ig domain. The extracellular domains of IgCAMs can be enzymatically cleaved by members of the ADAM (a disintegrin and metalloprotease) family (“Shedding”) (Maness and Schachner 2007).

sec.p: IgCAMs are transmembrane or glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) membrane-anchored glycoproteins with intracellular domains linking them directly or indirectly to the cytoskeleton, in addition to linking them to signaling pathways. By influencing assembly and stabilization of cytoskeletal elements like actin filaments and microtubules, IgCAMs can modulate cell motility and neurite outgrowth (Maness and Schachner 2007). These influences are mediated by interactions with scaffold molecules such as spectrin and growth-associated protein 43 (GAP-43) for NCAM, as well as ankyrin, ERM (ezrin, radixin, and moesin) proteins, and doublecortin for L1 family members (L1 and CHL1) (Table 1). IgCAMs also function as directly signaling and co-signaling molecules by, for instance, binding to and thus modulating the activity of receptors such as neuropilin-1, glial cell line–derived neurotrophic factor family receptor α1 (GFRα1), and fibroblast growth factor receptor (FGFR) (Table 1). Therefore, IgCAMs are not simply cell surface molecules mediating cell adhesion. They are implicated in downstream effects and can modulate, as a result of versatile binding properties, a variety of cellular processes by combinatorial patterns of trans- and cis-interaction partners (Table 1) (Loers and others 2005; Loers and Schachner 2007; Maness and Schachner 2007). Moreover, IgCAMs can impede or enhance these processes depending on the cell type in which they are expressed, their subcellular localization, molecular interaction partners, and spatial presentation of these interaction partners. For example, cis-interactions of L1 with integrins result in enhanced axon growth, whereas L1 cis-interactions with neuropilin-1 lead to growth cone collapse and inhibition of axon growth (Table 1). NCAM cleavage promotes neurite outgrowth in hippocampal neurons but down-regulates outgrowth and branching in cortical neurons in vitro (Maness and Schachner 2007). In addition, neurite outgrowth on astrocytes is reduced if CHL1 is simultaneously present on neurons and glial cells compared with expression on neurons or astrocytes alone (Jakovcevski, Wu, and others 2007).

caption.p: Major IgCAM Interaction Partners, Co-signaling Receptors, and Downstream Cellular Pathways

fn.p: Adapted from Loers and others (2005), Loers and Schachner (2007), Maness and Schachner (2007), Schmid and Maness (2008), and Walsh and Doherty (1997). GFRα1 = GDNF (glial cell line–derived neurotrophic factor) family receptor α1; FAK = focal adhesion kinase; FGFR = fibroblast growth factor receptor; PLCγ = phospholipase Cγ; DAG = diacylglycerol; AA = arachidonic acid; CaMKII-α = Ca2+/calmodulin-dependent protein kinase α, RPTPα = receptor protein phosphatase α; MEK = mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase; ERK = extracellular signal-regulated kinase; PKC = protein kinase C; p90rsk = p90 ribosomal s6 kinase; CK II = casein kinase II; PI3K = phosphatidylinositol-3′ kinase; BAD = Bcl-2 (B cell lymphoma 2)–associated death promoter.

sec.title: From the Cell In Vitro to the Injured Nervous System: The Challenge to Understand Regeneration
sec.p: Molecular and cell biological studies have provided a wealth of knowledge indicating that IgCAMs play key roles in determining the outcome of central nervous system (CNS) and peripheral nervous system (PNS) injury. Understanding of these functions in vivo is, however, a challenge considering the complexity of the nervous system and the wide spectrum of injury-evoked responses in different molecular and cellular contexts and functional circuitries. In the injured CNS of adult mammals, the overall failure of regeneration and the limited functional recovery are generally attributed to 1) restricted intrinsic capacity of neurons to regenerate their damaged axons and 2) nonpermissiveness for axon growth of the environment (Becker and Becker 2007a, 2007b; Giger and others 2010). In the adult PNS, axotomized neurons are capable of regeneration, and the environment in the damaged peripheral nerve supports axon growth (Giger and others 2010). Peripheral nerve regeneration is successful in that the target organ can be abundantly reinnervated but, paradoxically, the functional outcome after PNS injury is often poor (Lundborg and Rosén 2007; Scholz and others 2009). The IgCAMs on which this review is focused—namely, NCAM, L1, and CHL1—are generally considered, based on their in vitro properties, regeneration-promoting molecules. In line with this notion, in vivo evidence indicates that limited expression of L1 and NCAM in the adult CNS significantly contributes to regenerative failure. At the same time, recent studies unexpectedly revealed that IgSF molecules, such as CHL1 and L1, which were generally considered permissive molecules, limit recovery of function after CNS and PNS injury, respectively. The following sections summarize some major findings elucidating the diverse implementation of IgCAMs (NCAM, L1, CHL1, and MAG) in neural repair in adult mammals.

sec.title: IgCAMs Regulate the Intrinsic Axon Growth Potential of Injured CNS Neurons
sec.p: NCAM, L1, and CHL1 are expressed in most CNS neurons, and their expression is developmentally regulated (Bonfanti 2006; Hillenbrand and others1999; Hortsch 2003). The overall IgCAM expression is lower in adult than in embryonic brains, and the transition of an embryonic to adult pattern of protein expression is accompanied by changes in IgCAM glycosylation patterns, for example, reduction in NCAM polysialylation (i.e., “embryonic” NCAM expression; Kleene and Schachner 2004). Developmental changes in IgCAM expression have been proposed to underlie reduced regeneration (sprouting and elongation) of damaged CNS axons in adult compared with embryonic/postnatal birds and mammals (Blackmore and Letourneau 2006a, 2006b). Despite age-related decrease, the production of NCAM, L1, and CHL1 proteins is maintained at varying levels in most adult neurons (Bonfanti 2006; Hillenbrand and others 1999; Holm and others 1996; Horinouchi and others 2005; Nikonenko and others 2006). Several studies have shown a correlation between IgCAM expression level and axon regeneration into a regeneration-permissive peripheral nerve segment grafted into the CNS. Retinal ganglion cells and nigrostriatal and cholinergic neostriatal neurons express relatively high levels of L1 (and GAP-43) and are able to regenerate axons along the graft without L1 up-regulation (Becker and others 2001; Jung and others 1997; Woolhead and others 1998). Neurons in the thalamic reticular nucleus express low levels of L1 and CHL1 but are capable of up-regulating these proteins and also successfully regrow into the graft (Chaisuksunt, Campbell, and others 2000; Zhang Y and others 1995). Cerebellar deep nucleus neurons and precerebellar brainstem neurons also show a substantial capacity of axon regeneration accompanied by increased expression of L1, CHL1, and GAP-43 (Chaisuksunt, Zhang, and others 2000). In a mechanistic experiment, Y. Zhang and others (2005) demonstrated that Purkinje cells, which do not express or up-regulate L1, CHL1, or GAP-43 and do not regenerate into grafts (Chaisuksunt, Zhang, and others 2000), show remarkable axon regrowth when both L1 and GAP-43 are transgenically expressed in these cells. In line with the latter finding are observations in zebrafish showing that 1) the expression of L1.1, a homolog of mammalian L1, is increased after spinal cord injury in successfully regenerating descending axons but not in ascending projections that fail to regenerate (Becker and others 2005) and 2) morpholino-mediated reduction of L1.1 expression in descending neurons leads to deficient axon regrowth and functional recovery (Becker and others 2004). Without peripheral nerve grafting, however, axotomized mammalian neurons cannot regenerate their axons and, similar to poorly regenerating neurons in zebrafish, fail to up-regulate IgCAM expression (Jucker and others 1996; Mason and others 2003). The overall conclusion is that IgCAMs, most notably L1 in conjunction with its direct and indirect (NCAM) interaction partner GAP-43, are required for regeneration of injured CNS axons. We consider the failure of neurons to recapitulate the developmental growth-associated pattern of IgCAM expression a major limitation in adult neural repair and, therefore, expect them to be promising therapeutic targets in humans similar to what we have found them to be in rodents.

sec.title: IgCAMs as Extrinsic Inhibitors of Axonal Regeneration in the CNS
sec.p: Numerous molecules with axon growth-inhibitory potential have been identified in vitro and shown to be expressed in the intact and injured CNS: for instance, myelin-associated inhibitors (Nogo-A, MAG, and the oligodendrocyte myelin glycoprotein, OMpg), guidance molecules (semaphorins, ephrins, netrins), and extracellular matrix molecules (chondroitin sulfate proteoglycans and tenascin-R, among others) (Apostolova and others 2006; Becker and Becker 2007b; Fawcett 2009; Giger and others 2010; Loers and Schachner 2007). Clear evidence for a substantial contribution to poor regeneration and recovery after CNS injury exists for extracellular matrix molecules (Fawcett 2009). Despite considerable efforts to understand the functions of the myelin-associated proteins, their roles in vivo remain controversial (Giger and others 2010). A typical example for a controversy between expected and confirmed in vivo functions is the IgSF member MAG, the first discovered myelin neurite outgrowth-inhibiting molecule of the IgSF. MAG is expressed on the cell surface of oligodendrocytes during myelination and maintained at the periaxonal surface of compact myelin during adulthood (Bartsch and others 1989). Its direct opposition to and, thus, opportunity for direct interactions with the axonal surface and the finding that MAG inhibits neurite outgrowth of early postnatal cerebellar neurons (Filbin 2003) have suggested an axon growth inhibitory function of MAG in vivo. However, experiments using MAG-deficient versus wild-type mice showed that MAG deficiency did not influence the extent of axonal regrowth in the lesioned optic nerve and corticospinal tract (Bartsch and others 1995). This finding can be interpreted as an indication of redundancy in myelin-associated protein signaling rather than lack of function. Each of the three myelin-associated proteins—MAG, Nogo-66 (a Nogo-A domain), and OMgp—signals growth cone collapse and axon growth inhibition in vitro via two common receptors, the well-known GPI-anchored Nogo-66 receptor (NgR1) and the recently identified receptor PirB (paired immunoglobulin-like receptor B), an IgSF member (Atwal and others 2008). However, this redundancy hypothesis has not yet been confirmed. On the contrary, mice deficient in the expression of NgR1 (Kim JE and others 2004), PirB (Nakamura and others 2011; Omoto and others 2010), or all three ligands of these receptors (Lee and others 2010) failed to show prominent effects on axon regeneration and functional recovery after CNS trauma.

In contrast to MAG, the abilities of CHL1 to promote neurite outgrowth, neuronal migration, and survival in vitro had suggested that CHL1 promotes CNS regeneration. Recent work, however, revealed that functional recovery after compression of the thoracic spinal cord is more pronounced in CHL1-deficient mice than in wild-type littermates (Jakovcevski, Wu, and others 2007). Worse recovery in wild-type mice correlated with restricted regrowth of monaminergic axons in the distal (lumbar) spinal cord and was likely related to early and persistent up-regulation of CHL1 expression in glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP)–positive astrocytes (reactive astrocytes; see also the following section) at the lesion site (Fig. 2). Both in the intact spinal cord and in cultured astrocytes, enhanced expression of CHL1 and GFAP was induced by application of basic fibroblast growth factor (FGF). This up-regulation was abolished by inhibitors of the FGF receptor-dependent ERK, CaMKII, and PI3K signaling pathways. Most important, in homo- and heterogenotypic co-cultures of neurons and astrocytes, reduced neurite outgrowth was observed only if CHL1 was simultaneously present on both cell types. These findings suggest that CHL1 is a glial scar component that restricts posttraumatic axonal growth by homophilic binding mechanisms. Again cautioning against an easy extrapolation of observations from in vitro studies is the finding that CHL1, when substrate coated to measure neurite outgrowth in culture, promotes neurite outgrowth of wild-type neurons (Chen S and others 1999), although in vitro studies have been successfully used as first indicators of at least some functions of IgSF molecules.

caption.p: CHL1 expression in the injured mouse spinal cord. (A–B) Double immunofluorescence on a parasagittal section for CHL1 (red) and fibronectin (green) at the lesion site six weeks after compression spinal cord injury in a C57BL6/J mouse. Scale bar: A, 100 µm; B, 20 µm. (C) Immunoblot analysis of CHL1 expression at the lesion site at different time points after injury. Top: representative immunoblot for CHL1 (180-kDa band) and the loading control, GAPDH (glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate dehydrogenase). Bottom: CHL1 expression levels, as estimated by optical density measurements, in the intact spinal cords (set to 100%) and one day (d) to eight weeks (w) after injury as percentage of intact. Mean + SEM values (*P < .05 compared with intact, analysis of variance with Dunnett’s post hoc test; n = 5 mice per time point). Adapted from Jakovcevski, Wu, and others (2007).

sec.title: IgCAMs Render Permissive Properties to the Glial Scar
sec.p: Reactive astrogliosis is one of the prominent responses of the CNS to various insults (Sofroniew and Vinters 2010). In its most severe form seen after traumatic injuries or infarcts, astrogliosis is characterized by alterations in molecular expression patterns (e.g., up-regulation of GFAP), cell hypertrophy (enlargement of the cell body and processes), and proliferation (replication), leading to local accumulation of astrocytes and formation of a glial scar. A characteristic feature of the glial scar is its dense extracellular matrix produced by reactive astrocytes in association with other cell types such as fibromeningial and Schwann cells after traumatic spinal cord injury (SCI). The traditional view of the glial scar is that it represents an impermeable barrier for axon growth and cell migration. Indeed, inhibitory molecules such as chondroitin sulfate proteoglycans, tenascin-R, semaphorin-3A, ephrin-B2, slit proteins, and CHL1 are highly enriched in the glial scar (Fitch and Silver 2008; Giger and others 2010; Jakovcevski, Wu, and others 2007). However, the scar contains also axon growth– and cell migration–promoting IgCAMs, such as PSA-NCAM, which is expressed by astrocytes after SCI. L1 is expressed by Schwann cells that invade the injured spinal cord while reverting to more immature features when their myelin undergoes Wallerian degeneration due to loss of axonal support. With time after injury, the chronic CNS glial scar becomes more permissive as the expression of chondroitin sulfate proteoglycans and myelin-associated inhibitors is decreased and PSA-NCAM expression is increased (Camand and others 2004; Dusart and others 1999). This type of IgCAM expression promotes the ingrowth of axons into the scar. If the scar is enriched in PSA-NCAM by overexpression in astrocytes ( El Maarouf and others 2006) or in L1 by infusion of a soluble L1 fragment presenting the extracellular domain of L1 (Roonprapunt and others 2003), axon regrowth across the scar, even of regeneration-refractory axons such as the corticospinal ones, is significantly enhanced. These results show that the glial scar is not exclusively impermeable to regrowing axons, indicating another promising target for therapeutic interventions.

sec.title: IgCAMs Are Implicated In Injury-Induced CNS Plasticity
sec.p: Although true regeneration in the sense of regrowth of injured axons beyond the lesion site and target reinnervation does not occur to a substantial degree after CNS injury, plasticity by spared neurons is apparently pronounced. The current understanding of this phenomenon is limited, but a few studies have indicated a remarkable extent of remodeling after unilateral spinal cord injuries (dorsal or lateral hemisections). Injured corticospinal tract axons form proximal collateral sprouts that establish contacts with long-projecting propriospinal (spinal cord–intrinsic) neurons and thus regain functional connections with lumbar motoneurons (Bareyre and others 2004). Injury-induced sprouting into the distal spinal cord has also been documented for spared reticulospinal axons, projections responsible for initiation of walking (Ballermann and Fouad 2006). Also, it has been shown that reorganized propriospinal relay connections bypassing sites of injury are able to mediate spontaneous functional recovery and supraspinal control of stepping after interruption of long descending pathways (Courtine and others 2008). Axon sprouting and establishment of novel connections also occur in peri-infarct and connected cortical areas and correlate with functional recovery after stroke (Carmichael 2006). Considering the developmental roles of IgCAMs, it can be expected that they are essentially involved in plasticity after CNS injury, and several studies have provided evidence in support of this notion. L1 expression on sprouting axons has been observed after dentate gyrus deafferentation and fimbria-fornix lesions (Aubert and others 1998; Jucker and others 1996; Styren and others 1995). Transient up-regulation of PSA-NCAM expression in astrocytes and neurons—and thus an increase in the permissiveness of the local environment—occurs in areas of reactive sprouting after different experimental lesions, including transient global ischemia, fluid percussion injury, and dentate gyrus deafferentation (Aubert and others 1998; Emery and others 2000; Fox and others 2001; Jucker and others 1995; Styren and others 1995). Even remote responses to injury such as structural alterations in synapses in the motor cortex after SCI are associated with increased PSA-NCAM expression (Kim BG and others 2006). Furthermore, NCAM-deficient mice recover less efficiently than wild-type mice after focal lesion of the barrel cortex, and this impairment has been related to restricted remodeling of intact circuitries surrounding the lesion (Troncoso and others 2004). Not least, the finding of a differential impact on lumbar motoneuron perisomatic coverage after SCI in CHL1-deficient and wild-type mice provides evidence for the importance of IgCAMs in synaptic remodeling (Jakovcevski, Wu, and others 2007). Apart from structural remodeling, IgCAMs regulate the efficacy of synaptic transmission (Dityatev and others 2008). It is therefore likely that they are implicated in changes of synaptic transmission (facilitation, long-term potentiation) associated with adaptive and maladaptive responses to CNS lesions (Descalzi and others 2009; Di Filippo and others 2008). Future research on the involvement of IgCAMs in plasticity will be of major importance for understanding the mechanisms promoting and restricting recovery in the injured brain.

Development of neuropathic pain is a common complication of SCI and peripheral nerve injury likely associated with maladaptive synaptic transmission (Gwak and Hulsebosch 2011) and sprouting of small-diameter nociceptive (calcitonin gene-related peptide, CGRP) expressing axons in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord (Chaudhry and others 2006). Several studies have linked this spouting to L1 expression in CGRP-positive axons. After SCI, reduction of CGRP-positive axon growth has been observed in L1-deficient compared with wild-type mice (Deumens and others 2007; Hoschouer and others 2009). Thermal hyperalgesia after SCI develops in L1-deficient mice, but it becomes more attenuated with time compared with wild-type mice (Hoschouer and others 2009). An increase in L1-positive axons and attenuation of mechanical allodynia and thermal hyperalgesia after intrathecal application of the L1 antibody have been reported after sciatic nerve transection in rats (Yamanaka and others 2007). However, sprouting of CGRP-positive axons in the dorsal horn after dorsal rhizotomy is similar in L1-deficient and wild-type mice (Runyan and others 2007). And interestingly, CGRP-positive axonal sprouting induced by nerve growth factor overexpression in astrocytes after SCI is significantly reduced by co-expression of L1, possibly via a neuropilin-1/semaphorin-3A signaling mechanism (Chaudhry and others 2006). This finding is important regarding therapeutic approaches using L1 overexpression in the injured spinal cord, as it is for other neurite outgrowth-promoting molecules. Even if L1 contributes to development of neuropathic pain under certain conditions, transgenic expression or infusion of L1 is likely to suppress rather than enhance abnormal pain sensitivity. That overexpression of regeneration-promoting factors must not necessarily lead to allodynia and hyperalgesia has been shown for a combinatorial treatment with transplanted adult neural stem/progenitor cells, chondroitinase, and growth factors (Karimi-Abdolrezaee and others 2010). In contrast to L1, NCAM signaling has been proposed to play a critical role in the analgesic effect of glial cell–derived neurotrophic factor (GDNF) in neuropathic pain (Sakai and others 2008). Further studies on the influence of IgCAMs on neuropathic pain are of major clinical relevance considering that treatment of this complication in humans is extremely difficult (Woolf and Mannion 1999).

sec.title: Neuroprotection by IgCAMs
sec.p: The evidence for neuroprotective effects of IgCAMs in vivo is less abundant than the in vitro evidence, yet it is of significant importance regarding the substantial impact of secondary damage and cell death on the severity and outcome of CNS lesions. Neuroprotective functions of IgCAMs or related glycans have been indicated by findings in several injury models. Enzymatic removal of PSA results in loss of retinal ganglion cells in the intact adult retina of mice, and this loss is significantly exaggerated after optic nerve transection (Murphy and others 2009). Enhanced apoptosis and more severe impairment after SCI have been observed in NCAM-deficient compared with wild-type mice (Zhang S and others 2010). PSA-NCAM is up-regulated, in conjunction with heat shock protein 70 (HSP70), after hyperthermia, a treatment conferring resistance to kainate-induced neurodegeneration, and the neuroprotective effect of hyperthermia is abolished in the absence of PSA (Duveau and others 2007). In a mouse model of temporal lobe epilepsy, PSA-NCAM is up-regulated in the morphologically intact hippocampus contralateral to the site of kainate injection, and this expression enables survival of principal neurons via GDNF signaling (Duveau and Fritschy 2010). Neuroprotective effects have been reported after basic fibroblast growth factor (FGF-2) delivery to the injured spinal cord (Meijs and others 2004; Teng and others 1999), and it is plausible to assume that these effects are mediated via NCAM-FGFR signaling. Important for cell-based therapies, L1 overexpression in stem cells significantly improves their survival, as compared with nontransfected cells, after transplantation in a mouse model of Parkinson disease and after SCI (Chen J and others 2005; Cui and others 2010). Finally, interesting and promising from a clinical point of view is also the finding that centrally or systemically applied antibodies against MAG significantly reduce lesion volume and improve motor function after middle cerebral artery occlusion (Irving and others 2005).

sec.title: Differential Modulation of PNS Regeneration by IgCAMs
sec.p: PSA-NCAM is abundantly expressed in PNS axons and neurons as well as Schwann cells during embryonic development and up-regulated in these cell types after nerve injury in the adult rodent (Martini 1994; Martini and Schachner 1988). Expression of NCAM on both regenerating axons and Schwann cells has suggested that it fosters regeneration. In line with this notion is the finding that application of neutralizing antibodies against NCAM causes a delay in but does not compromise endplate reinnervation after gluteal nerve injury in mice (Langenfeld-Oster and others 1994). Constitutive ablation of NCAM in mice does not lead to an apparent delay in reinnervation, as indicated by similar rates of functional recovery within the first two months after sciatic nerve crush in NCAM-deficient and wild-type mice (Fey and others 2010). Initial endplate reinnervation also proceeds normally in the NCAM-deficient mouse, but this innervation becomes compromised with time after injury due to instability of the newly formed endplates, leading, by three months after injury, to deficits in neurotransmitter release, withdrawal of axons from reinnervated endplates, and loss of contractile muscle force (Chipman and others 2010). As a consequence, motor function at three months after injury is worse in NCAM-deficient than in wild-type mice (Fey and others 2010). These findings indicate that NCAM expression is required for long-term stability of reinnervated endplates. In addition, recent work has suggested that increased PSA-NCAM expression after femoral nerve injury is necessary for preferential targeting of regenerating motor axons to skeletal muscle as opposed to skin (Franz and others 2005, 2008), a phenomenon known as preferential motor reinnervation (Brushart 1988).

Similar to NCAM, L1 is expressed in axons and Schwann cells during embryonic and early postnatal development and up-regulated after nerve injury (Martini and Schachner 1988; Martini and others 1994), suggesting a beneficial role in regeneration in the adult PNS. Contrary to this hypothesis, regeneration experiments using the femoral nerve injury paradigm in mice revealed better functional recovery in L1-deficient mice compared with wild-type littermates (Guseva and others 2009). Improved regeneration in L1-deficient mice was also indicated by attenuated posttraumatic loss of motoneurons, enhanced precision of motor reinnervation, larger cell bodies of regenerated motoneurons, and diminished loss of inhibitory synaptic input to motoneurons. A possible explanation of the observed counterintuitive effects is that Schwann cell proliferation is strongly augmented in L1-deficient versus wild-type mice (Fig. 3), indicative of enhanced production of beneficial cytokines. Thus, it appears that L1 negatively regulates Schwann cell proliferation after nerve damage, which in turn restricts functional recovery by limiting the trophic support for regenerating motoneurons.

caption.p: Schwann cell proliferation in injured femoral nerves of L1-deficient (L1y/–) male mice and wild-type (L1y/+) male littermates. Longitudinal cryostat sections of 5 µm thickness from distal stumps of transected femoral nerves of L1y/– (A–F) and L1y/+ mice (A′–F′) dissected three to seven days after injury. Staining for the Schwann cell marker S-100 (A–C′) reveals higher numbers of S-100-positive cells in L1y/– mice (A–C) than in L1y/+ littermates (A′–C′). Staining of sections serial to those shown in panels A–C′ with an antibody against the proliferation marker Ki67 (D–F′) shows also higher numbers of proliferating cells in L1y/– mice than in L1y/+ mice at all time points studied. Scale bars in A and D indicate 50 and 100 µm for A–C′ and D–F′, respectively. Adapted from Guseva and others (2009).

sec.p: MAG is expressed by Schwann cells in the PNS and is down-regulated during the period of Wallerian degeneration after nerve injury (Martini and Schachner 1988). If Wallerian degeneration is delayed and myelin debris and thus MAG persist for a longer period in the distal stump of the injured nerve as in the C57BL/Wlds mouse, axonal regeneration is delayed, and genetic ablation of MAG in this mutant improves regeneration (Schäfer and others 1996). Application of antibodies against MAG enhances the speed of axonal regrowth after sciatic nerve injury (Tomita and others 2007) and accelerates preferential motor reinnervation after femoral nerve injury in mice (Mears and others 2003). These findings are consistent with an inhibitory role of MAG in peripheral nerve regeneration. Interestingly, however, application of an MAG-Fc fragment, but not MAG antibody, to the injured mouse sciatic nerve leads to significantly improved functional outcome (Tomita and others 2007). This positive effect of MAG has been attributed to inhibition of axonal branching at the lesion site via activation of RhoA and subsequent improvement of the precision of target reinnervation.

In intact adult rodents, CHL1 is expressed at higher levels in peripheral neurons than L1 (Jakovcevski, Wu, and others 2007), and its expression is up-regulated in neurons and Schwann cells after nerve injury (Zhang Y and others 2000). The functional role of this expression pattern is currently unknown. It will be interesting to study regeneration in the PNS of CHL1-deficient mice, especially considering the unexpected findings in L1-deficient mice described above.

sec.title: IgCAMs and Myelination in the Central and Peripheral Nervous System
sec.p: Poor remyelination of axons after CNS and PNS injuries is considered a factor contributing to limited functional recovery (Hildebrand and others 1985; Wu and Ren 2009). The role of IgCAMs in remyelination is still not well understood. Studies of the developing nervous system have suggested that L1 and MAG contribute to the success of myelination at its early stages (Martini and others 1994) and that down-regulation of PSA-NCAM is required for myelination (Jakovcevski, Mo, and others 2007; Martini 1994). Analyses of myelin in NCAM- and MAG-deficient mice revealed, however, minor deficits in compact myelin only if, in addition, the myelin protein P0 was genetically deleted (Carenini and others 1999). Enzymatic removal in PSA in the postnatal optic nerve of mice leads to only a transient increase in the number of myelinated internodes (Charles and others 2000). Expression of PSA-NCAM on demyelinated CNS axons has been proposed to inhibit remyelination in multiple sclerosis patients (Charles and others 2002), but experimental evidence has yet to support this notion. In contrast to the expected inhibitory role of PSA on myelination, application of a functional peptide mimic of PSA to the injured femoral nerve or injured spinal cord of adult mice led to a pronounced improvement of axonal myelination and functional recovery (Mehanna and others 2009, 2010). Although the mechanisms underlying these effects are currently unclear, the results indicate that PSA signaling is of functional importance in the injured CNS and PNS of mammals.

In peripheral nerves of adult L1-deficient mice, myelination is normal and remyelination after nerve injury is apparently not impaired (Dahme and others 1997; Guseva and others 2009). However, if L1 is transgenically overexpressed in adult mice under the control of the neuron-specific Thy-1 promoter, myelination of regenerated axons after femoral nerve injury is improved compared with wild-type mice (Guseva and others 2011). This finding shows for the first time that L1 plays an important role in myelination in vivo and indicates a potential target of L1-based therapies for nervous system repair.

sec.title: Therapeutic Approaches Using IgCAMs and Their Associated Glycans
sec.p: On the basis of knowledge acquired in experiments in vitro and in vivo on functional roles of IgCAMs in regeneration, researchers have devised and tested various therapeutic approaches in different animal models in recent years. One major finding of these therapeutic trials is that enrichment of the regeneration-hostile adult CNS environment with L1 is beneficial for repair of the CNS. After SCI, improvement of function associated with enhanced axon regeneration has been achieved by infusion of a soluble L1-Fc fragment in rats (Roonprapunt and others 2003) and overexpression of L1 in neurons and glial cells using an adeno-associated viral construct in mice (Chen J and others 2007). L1 overexpression in stem cells promotes their survival, differentiation, and migration after transplantation in vivo and increases their therapeutic potential in models of Huntington and Parkinson diseases and spinal cord injury in mice (Bernreuther and others 2006; Chen J and others 2005; Cui and others 2010; Ourednik and others 2009). Similar to L1, virally induced overexpression of PSA in the damaged CNS promotes axon growth ( El Maarouf and others 2006), and application of PSA peptide mimetics improves the anatomical and functional outcome after SCI in mice (Marino and others 2009; Mehanna and others 2010). Overexpression of L1 or PSA in transplanted Schwann cells leads to better, as compared with nontransfected cells, remyelination and functional recovery after SCI in mice (Lavdas and others 2010; Papastefanaki and others 2007). PSA and an NCAM-derived peptide have been shown to be beneficial for CNS repair by facilitating cognitive and motor recovery and diminishing neurodegeneration after traumatic brain injury in rats (Klementiev and others 2008). Finally, we should mention that peptide mimetics of PSA and HNK-1, a glycan shared by NCAM, L1, CHL1, MAG, and other recognition molecules, such as tenascin-C, are effective in promoting functional recovery after peripheral nerve injury in adult mice (Mehanna and others 2009; Simova and others 2006). The combined results unequivocally indicate beneficial functions of IgCAMs in neural repair and point to clinically feasible approaches to improve functional recovery after injuries in the PNS and CNS.

sec.title: Concluding Remarks
sec.p: The understanding of molecular and cellular phenomena determining the responses of the nervous system to injury and limiting restoration of function has significantly increased in recent years. It is now accepted that several IgCAMs are major players in the complexity of events associated with neural repair, including axonal regrowth, remyelination, and synaptic plasticity. Based on the knowledge of how these molecules restrict or promote regeneration, the design of promising therapeutic strategies for humans has emerged. However, our major knowledge of the functional roles of IgCAMs is restricted to only a few molecules and areas of research, and investigations on neural plasticity after injury and interactions of IgCAMs with the immune system have not yet received enough attention. Addressing these issues is a major challenge for future research and promise for further progress.

ack.p: The authors are grateful to Gabriele Loers for comments on the manuscript.
